discourse_list.title: Signal Request: Should we move to exponential rate stepping for stability fee polls?

content.content: Stability Fee increments in the polls should not be constant, they should be exponential. Advantages  Lets us react more strongly to changing market conditions if necessary, without having to trigger an exceptional poll in an emergency. Lets us do small scale tweaking if we want to try to find the lowest stability fee setting that maintains the peg, as some MKR holders seem to have voted for recently. Lets MKR holders fix the .5% precision ‘problem’, if they want to.  Disadvantages  It prevents us from making more precise changes in a single poll. If we wanted to make a specific change for say 3%, this would take two polls under the proposed system.  The following options would capture doveish/hawkish sentiment in both directions with a minimum of polling options: +8% +4% +2% +1% +0.5% No change -0.5% -1% -2% -4% -8%     Yes, we should do this. No, we should not do this.     0 voters

The post lists advantages and disadvantages of this proposal and suggests a set of options to capture doveish/hawkish sentiment. Can we try to come to a consensus on an ‘acceptable’ outcome rather than a perfect outcome? Remember that we can poll for a second change in stepping at a later date if we decide that the options are not fit for purpose. content.content: I don’t think we’re likely to see any more movement on the last poll. I’m still unsure whether 62% consensus is enough to get this through, but lets find out! This poll will determine what the on-chain poll looks like, my hope is that eventually we can set enough of a precedent that this won’t be necessary every time.      #1 Create an on-chain poll in the form: ‘Consensus Option, yes or no?’ - We implement the consensus option if Yes > No  #2 Create an on-chain poll in the form: ‘Which one of these suggested options do you want implemented (includes a status quo option)?’ - We implement the highest scoring (unless status quo wins, in which case we do nothing.)  #3 Create multiple on-chain polls, one for each option in the last poll, each has a yes/no option. - We implement the outcome with the highest ‘score’ so long as that ‘score’ is positive.  #4 This is not ready to go to an on-chain poll.  #5 I just want to see the results.     0 voters     Here are some of my thoughts on the above:  On #1: The consensus option is ‘0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 4’, This is fixed from this point, everyone has had time to signal if they were inclined to do so. I will be closing the previous polls. If we go with #1 we are allowing 1-person 1-vote to control which proposal makes it on-chain. This is putting a layer of democracy over our plutocracy. I would argue this is good, but others may not feel the same way.  #2 is plurality voting. It can result in splitting the vote, allowing status quo to win even though there is more consensus for some change, even if the flavour of that change can’t be agreed upon. I’m very against this option.  #3 is similar to the asset ranking poll. Here ‘score’ = ‘yes votes’ - ‘no votes’. We would be ranking solutions. This might be overkill, we’ve essentially done this already with 1-person 1-vote, but this way will give MKR holders the final say.  Based on suggestions that we need more calendar. I’ve set this poll to expire 1 week from today.

content.content: Looks good to me. Here’s the thread recap as I understand it:  Question, should we change the SF stepping to exponential? Started out with -8, -4, etc which polled at 74% approval Concern expressed from a user re: whales abusing large levers This lead to a poll for a range of possible options 14 days later 61% voted for -4…+4 Two weeks later another poll with the idea that consensus hadn’t been reached This poll was for a list of variations on the rate, resulted in a fairly even split of voters across four options LFW asks for compromise from previous poll voters, suggests 75% is a baseline for consensus support Two weeks later another poll from LFW with 75% approval for option -4…+4  Some takeaways,  How do we balance “good enough and can be tweaked later” vs. doing all the diligence we can up front? Did the process take too long or do we simply take as long as we need? How much consensus to we require? 50%, 75% more? Is it dependent on the criticality of the change? What is majority, quorum for us? Can we expect people to revisit old votes and recast them based on new data? How do we encourage people to seek capitulation?  All-in-all, a pretty successful example of governance in action, thank you to everyone who participated. I’ll schedule a new governance poll to start on Monday, September 23 at 4PM UTC. It will contain the questions as formatted above by @LongForWisdom.

content.content: I’m in the process of setting up the rate stepping governance poll for next week and it occurs to me now that there might be a lack of clarity about what the new polls will look like. In the past we used relative values in the polls, i.e. -4, -2, -1, etc., operating under the expectation that the Stability Fee executive would always be ratified before the Stability Fee poll started. It became apparent that wasn’t always the case, so we had ambiguity in the system where people who vote early in a poll could be voting for a ‘stale’ SF if it changes during the week. We then moved to absolute values. i.e. 10%, 11%, 12%, etc. In the wording of the current poll:     LongForWisdom:  If this proposal passes, each regularly scheduled stability fee poll will have the following polling options only: -4%, -2%, -1%, -0.5%, -0.25%, No change, +0.25%, +0.5%, +1%, +2%, +4%’   could imply that we are going back to relative. It is my understanding that we don’t want to do that so, assuming that the current fee is 12.5%, the next poll would have the options: 8.5, 10.5, 11.5, 12, 12.25, 12.5, 12.75, 13, 13.5, 14.5, 16.5 Does everyone feel that this format is understood?

content.content: So this is my bad. I hadn’t realised there was potential confusion between the relative/absolute thing. To clarify:  I didn’t use absolute values in the polling question because it is a general change that extends past the current SF level. I should have specified that these values are “Relative from the active stability fee, but absolute when described in each regular stability fee poll.” And then provided an example.  Sorry for the confusion, I’ll try to make sure everything is more precise in the future and has no room for misinterpretation.
